II. EMERGENCY WORK.As announced by the Prime Minister on the 19th October, certain schemes have been put in hand by the Local Authorities in conjunction with the Ministry of Transport and the Ministry of Health, and by the Local Authorities themselves, designed to secure work for unemployed men, preferentially ex-Service men. The following is the result at this date: (a.) New Arterial Roads.21,393 men employed up to date (in and around London, 2,784; Provinces, 18,609).(b.) Road Maintenance.It is estimated that employment has been provided for approximately 20,000 men over and above those ordinarily so employed.(c.) Housing (Acceleration of the Lay-Out of Roads and Sewers and Approved Housing Schemes).Men employed up to the 27th May, 3,976 (in and around London, 304; Provinces, 3,672).(d.) Lord St. Davids' Committee.Men employed on work other than the above up to the 27th May, 32,961 (in and around London, 5,702; Provinces, 27,259).(e.) Alternative Work in Government Establishments.War Office establishments: men employed up to the 28th May, 2,787 (in and around London, 2,069; Provinces, 718).Alternative work provided in Admiralty establishments: men employed up to the 28th May, 6,456 (in and around London, nil; Provinces, 6,456).(f.) Short-time in Government Establishments.Number of men who have found employment up to date as a result of the intro-duction of short-time system. Men employed-up to the 28th May: War Office estab-lishments, 2,029 (in and around London, 1,902; Provinces, 127) ; Admiralty estab-lishments, 3,667 (in and around London, 194; Provinces, 3.473).(g.) Office of Works Emergency Programme.The special Emergency Programme of decorating and repair work in GoVern-ment Departments by the Office of Works is now completed.(h.) Emergency Work found by Local Authorities. iTotal number of men employed up to the 27th May, 12,606 (in and around London, 2,857; Provinces, 9,749).Total labour employed on above schemes = 105,875.[6381] -" -\GENERAL.No improvement in the general industrial position is reported, and, in the absence of any settlement of the coal dispute, unemployment continues to increase. All the larger firms in the iron and steel trades have either closed down or are working short-time. A slight improvement, due to fresh repair contracts coming to hand, is reported in shipbuilding. The position in the textile trades remains unchanged, and, although a few firms are making use of oil fuel, the experiment has apparently not proved very successful. The lace and hosiery trades are almost at a standstill, but in the boot and shoe industry employment remains comparatively good, although short-time working has been generally adopted. In the pottery trade work is also practically suspended, and the fishing industry continues to be seriously affected by the lack of fuel. As reports for the week ended the 27th May have been received from only 374 Local Authorities out of 409 who were asked to furnish information, it is probable that the Relief Schemes which have been inaugurated by the Government and Local Authorities are finding employment for a number of men in excess of the figures given.III. 50,000 EX-SERYICE MEN TO BE TRAINED IN THE BUILDINGINDUSTRY.The industrial stagnation caused by the coal stoppage, and the consequent uncertainty of the outlook, have seriously interfered with the progress of this scheme. The employers, however, have set up District Committees in many of the more important industrial centres, and it is understood that they will shortly be posting notices on all jobs advising their workpeople that the job is only open to men willing to work with and assist in the training of ex-Service men taken on under the scheme. This action has already been taken in London by the Master Builders and also by the Office of Works.In addition steps are being taken to make it clear that contracts for building and constructional work in which the Government is financially interested will in general be confined to contractors who are employing men under the conditions of the scheme.In the meantime the total applications are 16,914. In the London and South-Eastern Division 7,276 men have applied, and the following are figures for other Divisions: South Midlands and Eastern Counties, 1,114; South-Western Counties, 1,419; West Midlands, 1,715; Yorkshire and East Midlands, 1,556 ; North'-Western Counties, 2,230; Northern Division, 438; Scotland, 972; Wales, 194.About 60 men have been taken on under the scheme, chiefly by the Office of Works in the London area; in addition the London employers Committee have allocated a further 130 men among employers in the area, and these men should be starting work immediately.IY.
